note.body: Excellent, the test looks great. Many thanks!

target_title: gobject: handle gjs_context_dispose unroots wrappers but ObjectInstance still exists

note.body:
Thanks for the pointer! I managed to get an automated test working after I realized the `setTimeout` referencing `win` was causing `win` to be GC-ed in the later `SHUTDOWN` GC after we released all native objs instead of originally in context dispose GC where we had the problem. In my test I'm using a WeakRef to get around this with idle_add for better test style.

This test fails on master and passes in this branch. I also added `GTK_A11Y=none` to not have unrelated criticals triggering systemtap while running on the CI.

target_title: Timeout callback tries to run during garbage collection

note.body:
@ptomato I believe browsers use a different approach: the only things that can run concurrently with GC do so on a separate thread, and that thread is not allowed to call back into JavaScript under any circumstances.  It can only send messages to it.  Since GJS runs on the GTK (main) thread, this isn’t an option.

Why would waiting for GC to complete deadlock?  For there to be a deadlock, the GC would need to be waiting on something else, and that should never happen unless I have misunderstood something.

target_title: [Feature Request] Provide a method of determining the runtime's path from JS code

note.body:
This depends on a GLib feature request that seems unlikely to be prioritized: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/issues/31

See discussion in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gjs/-/issues/373.

target_title: gobject: handle gjs_context_dispose unroots wrappers but ObjectInstance still exists

note.body:
Thanks! This is fine to merge. If you do manage to come up with a programmatic test, that'd be even better, so I'll leave it open for a little while in case you or anyone else has an idea.

I wonder if the bug depends on control passing to a signal handler. That might be why programmatically calling `close()` doesn't trigger it.

note.body: Tried writing a test based on the reproducer but found it doesn't surface if `win.close()` was called programmatically instead of clicking with any kind of `setTimeout`.

This might be related to specific Mutter Meta methods? The `error` param for `meta_context_terminate_with_error` in `ui/init.js`'s catch is gir transfer=none but it's stealing the error https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/-/blob/main/src/core/meta-context.c#L603. The same GError that GJS copied and `meta_context_run_main_loop` gets is then being freed after invoke.

The double free is gone with transfer=full but some main loop asserts then fails:

```
Gjs:ERROR:../gjs/mainloop.h:51:Gjs::MainLoop::~MainLoop(): assertion failed: (g_ref_count_compare(&m_hold_count, 1) && "mismatched hold/release on main loop")
Bail out! Gjs:ERROR:../gjs/mainloop.h:51:Gjs::MainLoop::~MainLoop(): assertion failed: (g_ref_count_compare(&m_hold_count, 1) && "mismatched hold/release on main loop")
```

target_title: object: Use property accessors to get/set properties when defined

note.body:
I'm not a big fan of fallible constructors. Maybe either split it into an infallible constructor and a fallible `init()` method, or scrap the constructor and make a static `create()` method. (either of these methods could return `GErrorResult<ObjectPropertyInfoCaller*>`)

Maybe the `init()` method is cleaner. Otherwise you have to deal with two sources of failure at the same time when calling it with `SimpleWrapper::new_for_type()`: the function invoker prep could fail, but the JS Object allocation could also fail.

target_title: Avoid allocating stack frame labels if profiler is not running
Don't suppress irregular IWYU output

note.body:
@3v1n0 made an attempt already in !866 but this needs to be updated to not buffer all of the output until the end. Otherwise you get an extremely long wait with no feedback, while IWYU runs on all the files.

```diff
--- a/tools/run_iwyu.sh
+++ b/tools/run_iwyu.sh
@@ -43,11 +43,13 @@ fi
 
 echo "files: $files"
 
+output=$(mktemp --tmpdir -t "iywu-output-XXXXXX")
+
 IWYU="python3 $(which iwyu_tool || which iwyu-tool || which iwyu_tool.py) -p ."
-IWYU_TOOL_ARGS="-I../gjs"
+IWYU_TOOL_ARGS="-I$SRCDIR/gjs"
 IWYU_ARGS="-Wno-pragma-once-outside-header"
 IWYU_RAW="include-what-you-use -xc++ -std=c++17 -Xiwyu --keep=config.h $IWYU_ARGS"
-IWYU_RAW_INC="-I. -I.. $(pkg-config --cflags gobject-introspection-1.0 mozjs-128)"
+IWYU_RAW_INC="-I$SRCDIR -I. -I.. $(pkg-config --cflags gobject-introspection-1.0 mozjs-128)"
 PRIVATE_MAPPING="-Xiwyu --mapping_file=$SRCDIR/tools/gjs-private-iwyu.imp -Xiwyu --keep=config.h"
 PUBLIC_MAPPING="-Xiwyu --mapping_file=$SRCDIR/tools/gjs-public-iwyu.imp"
 POSTPROCESS="python3 $SRCDIR/tools/process_iwyu.py"
@@ -63,7 +65,7 @@ for FILE in $SRCDIR/gi/arg-types-inl.h $SRCDIR/gi/js-value-inl.h \
 do
     if should_analyze $FILE; then
         if ! $IWYU_RAW $PRIVATE_MAPPING $(realpath --relative-to=. $FILE) \
-            $IWYU_RAW_INC 2>&1 | $POSTPROCESS; then
+            $IWYU_RAW_INC 2>&1 >> "$output"; then
             EXIT=1
         fi
     fi
@@ -83,7 +85,7 @@ for FILE in $SRCDIR/gi/*.cpp $SRCDIR/gjs/atoms.cpp $SRCDIR/gjs/byteArray.cpp \
     $SRCDIR/libgjs-private/*.c
 do
     if should_analyze $FILE; then
-        if ! $IWYU $FILE -- $PRIVATE_MAPPING $IWYU_TOOL_ARGS | $POSTPROCESS; then
+        if ! $IWYU $FILE -- $PRIVATE_MAPPING $IWYU_TOOL_ARGS >> "$output"; then
             EXIT=1
         fi
     fi
@@ -94,7 +96,7 @@ if ( should_analyze $SRCDIR/gjs/jsapi-dynamic-class.cpp || \
     should_analyze $SRCDIR/gjs/jsapi-class.h ); then
     if ! $IWYU $SRCDIR/gjs/jsapi-dynamic-class.cpp -- $PRIVATE_MAPPING \
         $IWYU_TOOL_ARGS \
-        -Xiwyu --check_also=*/gjs/jsapi-class.h | $POSTPROCESS; then
+        -Xiwyu --check_also=*/gjs/jsapi-class.h >> "$output"; then
         EXIT=1
     fi
 fi
@@ -103,7 +105,7 @@ fi
 for STEM in gjs/context gjs/mem gjs/profiler modules/cairo; do
     if should_analyze $SRCDIR/$STEM.cpp; then
         if ! $IWYU $SRCDIR/$STEM.cpp -- $PRIVATE_MAPPING $IWYU_TOOL_ARGS \
-            -Xiwyu --check_also=*/$STEM-private.h | $POSTPROCESS; then
+            -Xiwyu --check_also=*/$STEM-private.h >> "$output"; then
             EXIT=1
         fi
     fi
@@ -112,11 +114,19 @@ done
 for FILE in $SRCDIR/gjs/console.cpp $SRCDIR/installed-tests/minijasmine.cpp
 do
     if should_analyze $FILE; then
-        if ! $IWYU $FILE -- $PUBLIC_MAPPING $IWYU_TOOL_ARGS | $POSTPROCESS; then
+        if ! $IWYU $FILE -- $PUBLIC_MAPPING $IWYU_TOOL_ARGS >> "$output"; then
             EXIT=1
         fi
     fi
 done
 
+if [ $EXIT -ne 0 ]; then
+    cat "$output"
+fi
+
+if ! $POSTPROCESS < "$output"; then
+    EXIT=1
+fi
+
 if test $EXIT -eq 0; then echo "No changes needed."; fi
 exit $EXIT
```

target_title: Incorrect value of constant larger than 32 bits

note.body:
From debugging inside `gjs_value_from_constant_info`, gi seems to be giving us the truncated value. In the generated `gir` file I see the type is `gint`, which is `int` = max 4 bytes = 32 bits? https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gobject-introspection/-/blob/main/tests/scanner/Regress-1.0-expected.gir#L66

If I manually edit it to `<type name="guint64" c:type="guint64"/>` and `g-ir-compiler` again, then I get the correct result of `10000000000` in GJS.

target_title: console: persist REPL history to user defined path

note.body: Thanks for the catch, I went with solution 2 and a construct time property for more flexibility. `gjs/console.cpp` main() sets this property using the `gjs_console_get_repl_history_path` helper. Embedders can do something similar in their respective main methods and read_history.

target_title: console: persist REPL history to user defined path

note.body: Thanks for the revisions. I like it! Unfortunately I noticed something about making sure we read in the history on startup, that I failed to notice yesterday.

target_title: console: persist REPL history to user defined path

note.body:
I realized that if a program embeds the interpreter by creating its own GjsContext object, instead of executing the `gjs-console` binary, this code won't be reached. That's potentially a problem because we won't read in the history file, but if the debugger or console module are used, we will overwrite it, so it'll be reset.

One solution could be to read in the history in several places, like when initializing the debugger and when importing the console module.

Another could be to make the history path a construct property of GjsContext, and disable history logging by default, but enable it here when GJS is started via the `gjs-console` binary.

target_title: console: persist REPL history to user defined path

note.body:
I'd say something like "under the XDG cache folder, usually `~/.cache/`" so that readers don't have to call the function for themselves to get an idea of where the file lives.

Small nitpick, could we remove the dot from the filename? The dot makes sense if it's being put in the user's home folder, but in the cache folder it's actually better if it's visible by default.

target_title: console: persist REPL history to user defined path

note.body: I'd suggest using an auto pointer here. e.g., `Gjs::AutoChar default_history_path = ...`, remove the `g_free`s, and `return default_history_path.release()` in the last line.

target_title: console: persist REPL history to user defined path

note.body:
Thanks for the review! A default location when "" definitely sounds good, I've added that using the path `g_build_filename(g_get_user_cache_dir(), ".gjs_repl_history", nullptr)` since the other runtimes also use dot files without any extensions.

Also refactored logic into its own functions under `util/console.cpp` for reusability.

target_title: console: persist REPL history to user defined path
console: persist REPL history to user defined path

note.body:
Thank you, this looks great!

As a further improvement, how about a default location for the history file? Node and Deno have this. If you don't set the environment variable, they'll write the history to the default location; to turn it off, you set `NODE_REPL_HISTORY=` to a blank value. I'd suggest something like `g_build_filename(g_get_user_cache_dir(), "gjs", "repl_history.txt")` for the default location.

If you'd prefer to leave that for another time, fine to merge this now.

target_title: Various maintenance

note.body:
I'm not sure about bringing in the bounds-checking stuff with `memset_s` - I've added the `__STDC_WANT_LIB_EXT1__` stuff to `config.h` but it never does seem to compile. [Gnulib](https://git.savannah.gnu.org/gitweb/?p=gnulib.git;a=blob;f=lib/memset_explicit.c;h=a5d2b00b7ea24db1d9033e816fc88f9336bfe4fe;hb=HEAD)'s implementation might be an option if the license is compatible?

On the other hand, this isn't secure data. I read up on the optimization and the problem seems to be that you can't use memset to zero out secure data because it isn't guaranteed to be erased if the pointer is never used later. In our case, if the pointer is never used later, I think it's probably fine if it doesn't get erased?

target_title: doc: Add application Aurora Toolbox written in GJS

note.body:
Aurora Toolbox is a application that allows you to simplify the adaptation to the Aurora OS ecosystem. In this application, you can install all the necessary tools for working with Aurora OS:

Aurora SDK.
Aurora PSDK.
Flutter SDK.

And also interact with devices and the emulator. Manage Aurora CLI settings - the basis for this application. And prepare your VS Code to work with Flutter for Aurora OS.

The application supports 2 languages: English and Russian. Documentation is only in Russian:
https://keygenqt.github.io/aurora-toolbox

target_title: Classes implementing widget templates should override GObjectClass.dispose

note.body:
This is probably an issue that requires some design and discussion before creating a merge request.

I'd start by getting a full understanding of the problem, by writing a program that creates a custom type deriving from Gtk.Widget and needs to be able to call `dispose_template`. Then I'd have a look at `modules/core/Gtk.js` to see where `init_template` is called and understand the sequence of operations there.

Then, hopefully, you could make some sort of suggestion to discuss in this issue thread about how to solve it, possibly with a proof of concept on a branch. Some example questions that might need to be answered are:
- Does it need to happen differently between GTK 3 and 4?
- Would it happen automatically or would the developer need to opt in in their code?
- How would we avoid the situation where we try to call into JS code during GObject dispose, after the JS engine is already shut down? (which is the reason this issue exists in the first place)
- What would be the mechanism? (some ideas: FinalizationRegistry, adding an internal `_instance_dispose` method, or handling it entirely in C++)

After agreeing on how to implement it, you could open a merge request. The solution should have tests in `installed-tests/js/testGtk4.js` (and `installed-tests/js/testGtk3.js` if applicable.)

target_title: GjsAutoError double free

note.body:
"frees the GError" in the doc comment of `gjs_throw_gerror` seems to just be incorrect? I think it dates from before auto pointers.

If we want it to do that, the function signature should be `GjsAutoError&&` and not `const GjsAutoError&`, but I don't see it freeing anything. It copies the GError pointer before storing it anywhere. So I'd probably look elsewhere for the problem.

note.body: OK, that looks promising. I did 30 runs of the test with that patch applied; 29 passed, the other one failed because the VM went to emergency mode on a reboot for some reason (not this bug). I did 15 runs without that patch applied, and six of them failed; two look slightly different, but four were definitely this bug. So, the patch definitely looks like it fixes it.
